STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL
October 19, 1936
Mr. H.
VIce President for China,
Pan American Airways Company,
DM 10/28
507 Dollar Blag., 51 Canton Rd.,
Shanghai, China.
Dear Mr. Bixby:
which you enclosed original of Permit losued by the Director of
I have received your letter No. 456,
of September
with
vices at long Kong, granting P.A.A. the right to operate in Hong Kong
for a period of twelve months.
It was something of a shock to me to
discover that this permit had been issued to Pan American Airways, Inc.
because,
of course, trans-Pacific service is operated by Pan American
Airways
Company and all our correspondence with the British with reference
to Hong Kong rights refers specifically to "Company."
I can*t imagine
where the Director d
Air Services ever got the idea of putting in the
name of Pan American Airways, Inc.
I immediately cabled you to have this
changed and as it is obviously merely a clerical error feel sure you will
have no difficulty, but, of course, it leaves us without a valid pernit
for that much longer.
that it will not interfere with
Airways Company's plane.
With regard to the text of the permit, you call attention to
the changed wording in Section 1.
Of course, this is not nearly so
satisfactory as the wording in the letter from the British Air Ministry,
although it would amount to pretty much the same thing if the British
wished to cancel.
there is a good deal of difference between
an automatic cancellation,
and a mere right to cancel.
For example, if
there were some delay in negotiations looking to the extension of
rights to the British after rights had been granted to some other nation,
presumably this permit would be invalid during that period, whereas under
the former wording this permit could have remained in effect until such
British gave up hope of obtaining the reciprocal rights.
cannot understand why the Colonial authorities in Hong Kong
thought it necessary to change the language proposed by their home govern-
ment.
The words typed onto the
end of the pernit "as circumstances
may require"
are decidedly vague and the more you think about them the
less you can understand what they are intended to mean.
This again seems
to have been a contribution by the Hong Kong authorities.
On the whole, of course, we feel that there is nothing to do
but to accept this permit in its present form and to see what developments
are during the first year;
this, of course, subject to the change in the
name of the company which is imperative.
One reason we do not like the language of Section 1 in the present
permit is that it makes it appear as though this Company had made a sort of
trade and given assurances, if not guarantees, that certain rights would be
extended to the British and that our rights would be cancelled if we did not

October 19, 1936
Mr. H. M. Bixby, - #2.
make good on these guarantees.
of
course, that is not at all true and it
should be obvious to anyone that this Company cannot give any
assurances
as to what action the United States Government will take on any given
due toch as it were a natest per at tad bee at be senten
having been negotiated, I assume that we cannot be held responsible by
anyone for the language it contains.
I have just received your long and very interesting personal
letter of September 21 discussing a number of confidential
subjects.
lotte to the ile last e
of course, before you learned that Mr. Trippe was himself
It will be a great help to you, I am sure, to have
the opportunity to cover these important matters with him personally and
I shall
do.
be much interested to learn of his reactions and what you decide to
I have no comment to make and I am entirely in agreement with all of
your observations except that I am a little bit sceptical with regard to
your listing as one of
our assets in CNAC "our interest in Route 3."
Due to our failure during the last three years to conclude any permanent
or long term agreement with CNAC covering the operations of Route 3 it woudd
seem that our interest in Route 3 is wholly dependent upon a temporary
operating agreement, cancellable by our Chinese friends on 30 days' notice.
This seems to be a rather precarious ground for bargain and sale.
I refer now to your letter of September 26, addressed to Mr. Van
Zandt with regard to the extension of Imperial and K.N.I.L.M. to Manila, in
which you make the suggestion that it would be a good thing if we could
arrange to have the Philippine domestic lines, with our participation,
meet the foreign airlines outside the Philippines or possibly you also
have in mind meeting the foreign airlines at a port of entry
coast of the Philippine Islands.
With regard to this plan, I would like to
submit a thought:
The establishment of a precedent in the
under which foreign international operators would be compelled to turn over
their traffic to Philippine domestic companies at a point just outside the
Philippines or on the coast (border) might be very
embarrassing so far as
Pan American Airways System as a whole is concerned.
You can readily see
that if this practice were adopted by just a few countries in our Latin
American field, it might paralize our whole system.
It is, in fact,
our
No.
1 nightmare
that someday we may be faced with the demand that our
international
planes stop at a frontier and turn over the traffic to a
domestic company to carry through that country and turn over in turn to a
domestic company of the next country and so on.
I do not need to elaborate
on this as you can readily think it out for yourself.
The mere fact that
we participate in the ownership of the domestic company would not improve
the situation very much,
and not at all as regards Washington.
Of course,
the Philippines are not vatin America and it may be that some plan could be
worked out
there which would not
embarrass us elsewhere, or it may be that
we are going to be faced with this difficulty in any case, but the above will
give you something to raminate on in your spare time, if
you have any, and
will also serve as a reminder although none is probably needed,
that
anything we do even in the farthest outpost of the system is liable to
have iss serious repercussions elsewhere.
Yours very truly,
S. F. Morgan.
